sentences.sentence: Responses to an Opinion video by Alexander Stockton.
Also: Elect the attorney general; friendship memories; a leadership gap.To the Editor:Re “'What's My Life Worth?'

The Big Business of Denying Medical Care,” by Alexander Stockton (Opinion video, March 14), about prior authorization:Mr. Stockton's video captures a current snapshot of an important truth about medical insurance in our country and in doing so does a service to all citizens by making them aware of this threat to themselves and their families.The immediate truth is that medical insurance companies are inadequately regulated, monitored and punished for their greed.
In their current iteration they are bastions of greed, power and money.
They need to be reined in.But there are other truths as well.

Some physicians, just like some pharmaceutical companies, are unable to contain their greed and allow avarice to cloud their judgment, compromise their ethics and in some cases cross the line to Medicare fraud or other illegal activity.Medical care in our country is very big business involving billions of dollars.
Without proper controls, regulation and monitoring, malfeasance follows.

The challenge in such a complex and multifaceted context is how to implement such controls and monitoring without making things worse.Ross A. AbramsJerusalemThe writer, a retired radiation oncologist, is professor emeritus at Rush University Medical Center in Chicago.To the Editor:The Times's video exploits tragic outcomes and does not mention basic important facts about the limited yet key role of prior authorization in ensuring that patients receive evidence-based, affordable care.Prior authorization is used fora limited setof medical services ᅳ most often for treatments, tests and certain medications that are high-cost and/or high-risk.Coverage decisions for treatments, surgeries or procedures follow clinical recommendations from leading medical societies, clinical experts and federal health authorities.

In cases where prior authorization is used, it's designed to ensure that clinical care aligns with evidence-based recommendations ᅳ not to deny or discourage patients from getting the care they need.Health plans are constantly evaluating coverage policies as new evidence emerges, and where the data on patient safety and outcomes are proven, the use of prior authorization has fallen sharply.The approval process needs to be seamless for all parties, and health plans have broadly implemented electronic processes and review.

We encourage all providers to adopt the basic technology needed to ensure timely coordination on patient care.Despite efforts to advance evidence-based medicine, consumers still bear up to a staggering$935 billioncost burden from administrative waste and inappropriate care.Ignoring those facts does a disservice to readers and those actively looking for balanced consideration of the significant cost and quality challenges in our health system.Mike TuffinWashingtonThe writer is the president and C.E.O.

of AHIP, the national trade association representing the health insurance industry.To the Editor:This video does an excellent job of revealing one very commonly used practice by health insurance companies: requiring prior authorization for treatments or medications, especially very expensive ones.

It often results in bad outcomes for the patients due to the denial or delay of care.Because of our reliance on for-profit corporate entities to provide health insurance, profit gets priority over the health of the patient.
This does not occur in most other rich countries where the government provides health care.We must eliminate this expensive middleman that adds cost but no value to the system.

Combating the lobby of these profit-seeking companies, which are very rich and powerful, is difficult, but it must be done if we are to have health justice.Here in New York State, passing theNew York Health Actwould help accomplish this.
Please demand that your legislators pass this law.

Your health or even your life may depend on it.Elizabeth R. RosenthalLarchmont, N.Y.The writer is a retired dermatologist.To the Editor:I wasn't sure if I was alone in feeling as if something in our society has gone terribly wrong.

This Opinion piece explains the reality I've been living as a physician in America, and ᅳ quite simply put ᅳ is the single most important health care journalism story I have ever seen.Thank you.Jenifer LightdaleChestnut Hill, Mass.The writer is president of the North American Society of Pediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology and Nutrition.Elect the U.S. Attorney GeneralTo the Editor:Re “Jack Smith and Robert Hur Are the Latest Examples of a Failed Institution,” by Jack Goldsmith (Opinion guest essay, nytimes.com, March 12):Mr. Goldsmith is correct about all the problems in the proliferation of special counsels.
His solution is the elimination of special counsels.

That, however, does not address the underlying problem: that the attorney general of the United States is a political appointee, and therefore there is an inherent conflict of interest any time a potential prosecution has any political implications.It is time for the country to follow the example ofthe majority of statesand have an elected ᅳ and therefore independent ᅳ attorney general.Such a change would, of course, require an amendment to the Constitution, but unlike partisan proposals for amendments such as repeal of the Second Amendment or life beginning at conception, an amendment to elect the attorney general should have the support of both parties.Republicans claim that the Justice Department has been weaponized against the Jan. 6 defendants and against Donald Trump.

Democrats fear that a second Trump administration will weaponize the Justice Department.Electing the attorney general would not guarantee impartiality ᅳ any elected official is political ᅳ but it would mean that attorneys general would be independent of the president, who could no longer fire them.

It might even help to reduce the heat of current political discourse.James FogelBronxThe writer is a former assistant district attorney and a retired New York City Criminal Court judge.Friendship MemoriesTo the Editor:Re “The Friends Who Got Away,” by Frank Bruni (Opinion, March 16):I loved Mr. Bruni's essay about the sadness of seeing good friends drift away.

I could strongly relate, having moved from place to place for my entire life.It's easy to be overwhelmed by yearning for old friendships, but in recent years I have started looking at it with a new perspective: It's natural for friends to drift apart because of changing circumstances.

Rather than be sad, I simply feel lucky that all of these wonderful people were a part of my life, however briefly.I have some beautiful memories to sift through when I am feeling nostalgic, and I hope that my old friends also think of me from time to time with a smile.Nancy MatsunagaCroton-on-Hudson, N.Y.A Leadership GapTo the Editor:“Surviving the Ugliness of It All,” by David Brooks (column, March 8), is a very good analysis of America today.

Unfortunately, our current political leaders do not deserve to be even discussed in the same breath as Lincoln, Roosevelt or Churchill.It is so very sad that in this nation of more than 330 million we have such a poor choice of candidates for president.Charles ToubinAustin, TexasThis article appeared in print on page A23.
